one piece of knowledge for you, Ubuntu comes "clean" and free. To enable AVI video playback, flash/mp3 encoding, and many other multi-media related abilities you will have to install non-free software, which means 1)enable unsupported (and sometimes dangerous) software downloads in /etc/apt/sources.list 2)sudo apt-get install...[non-free software titles here]

this is usually safe by and large, but my advice is to disable those non-free software sources when you have the basic stuff you need for a working multi-media system to keep your system as close to stable as possible. Thats all.
By "version for linux" do you mean software that pretty much does all the same stuff?
You won't find it in a single program for linux, but Amarok or a fork from that project probably comes the closest
